instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi guys I’m after good adhesive sealants after iv done some jumpering on board. 

Anyone recommended a good one 

cheers

threads.message: [url]https://www.google.com/search?q=conformal+spray&client=firefox-b&source=lnms&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip94-cs-zdAhWqJcAKHU00CSEQ_AUICSgA&biw=1008&bih=484&dpr=1.67[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Cheers for that 

I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no liquid damaged it’s clean board missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> on power supply I’m getting 0.031 Am I thinking it’s 
dead cpu. S4 en is missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Is a long way to diagnose dead CPU; at least with the info posted...

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> doesn't even pulse?
Did you check basic signals from Power On Sequence?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
hi checked all these
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.60v ok
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5</SIGNAL>   8.60v ok 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HSO</SIGNAL> 8.60v ok 
dcin isol     8.60v ok
dcin g3h    8.60v ok
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G</SIGNAL>  3.42v ok
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3</SIGNAL> 3.00v ok 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>   5.00v ok 
pp5vs4     5.00v missing
s4 en missing
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> missing"
Doesn't even pulse???

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> plusing yes
smc _adpter_en 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.035v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUB_L</SIGNAL> 3.321v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> plusing yes"
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> should pulse too.
Check all big coils for pulse.
<SIGNAL>AL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too?

BTW, always better to check for pulses on power rails with o-scope...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> PULSING YES
<SIGNAL>AL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> PULSING YES
S4 EN PULSING YES 

ALL COILS PLUSING APART FROM L7560 AND L7130
ALL CHECKed WITH O-SCOPE

I HAD SCOPE AT 200mV

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"ALL COILS PLUSING"
So L7310/20 pulse too?

"APART FROM L7560 AND L7130"
Is normal, these have steady voltage.
I was reffering to the rest of coils.

The o-scope should catch peak level of a power rail, or signal.

Check if pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> Pin 3 7 are both pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"So L7310/20 pulse too?"

Check SPI termination resistors and traces for <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
Don't forget to look at <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
hi L310/20 pluse too
checked all spi termination resistors all look ok trace <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> ok 
check <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> all good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Don't look, measure...

Check for short, or low resistance on the power rails from page 58.
Also check <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Hi no short or low resistance but <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7870</CHIP>
pin 1 0v
pin 2 un
pin 3 0v
pin 4 3.2v
pin 5 gnd
pin 6 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
L7820 pulsing?
Any short there?
If not, heck voltages for <CHIP>U7820</CHIP>.
Same <SIGNAL>1V8_S3</SIGNAL> should go to <CHIP>U7870</CHIP>.

However check pins 1, 3, 6 of <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> for pulse, not for steady voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7870</CHIP>
pin 1 0v plusing
pin 2 un
pin 3 0v plusing
pin 4 3.2v
pin 5 gnd
pin 6 0v plusing

l7820 0v plusing diode mode 0.665 both side 

<CHIP>U7820</CHIP>
pin 1 3.2v
pin 2 0v plusing
pin 3 0v plusing
pin 4 3.2v
pin 5 gnd
pin 6 0v plusing
pin 7 gnd
pin 8 0v plusing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Try new BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: You are the man got a new bios powered on straight way no problems

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Be sure to have clean ME region...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Will you recommend a  good bios flasher and we’re to get the files from cheers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
TL866, or Medusa 2 if you mainly work MacBook boards.
Medusa 2 doesn't require desolder SPI chip and can even clean the ME region directly on the board...

When you need BIOS dumps post on the forum, if Google didn't help you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Why people buy f***g dumps from eBay, I never understand.
You pay subscription here, which allows you to get correct dumps, when needed...

Check all traces and resistors around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
Post backup here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos,
To get correct dumps should we ask each time for the specific one we need or there is a database where to directly download from?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I don't know about any online database.
Is better to ask here, I do not recommend wasting time with vinafix dumps.
Other webs have not confirmed dumps too, I suppose...
